section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need the Number Cards with dots for subitizing.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: As we read Five Creatures, we talked about the different creatures in the family. Can anyone remember how many creatures are in the book?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Revisit the Vocabulary Let’s review the word creatures. Review creatures Vocabulary Card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, you will see a card with dots on it and quickly say how many dots you see.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Point to one child and hold up one Number Card with dots. What number is this?
Repeat Continue the activity until each child has had a chance to practice with several different cards.
Extend Make sets of one to five objects such as crayons or buttons and have children tell how many are in the sets by looking at them.

Talk About Subitizing Have children think about situations when they know how many of something they see without counting. Many of them will be able to subitize one or two already. Have children point to examples of one item and two items around the room.

Slow the activity down for children who need extra support. Allow them to point to each dot on the card as they count. You may need to count aloud with them. Remind them that the last number they say is the number of dots on the card.
Show each dot card for two seconds or less to each child. Start with the cards showing the dice patterns and then continue with the more complicated random patterns of dots.

For children who may need more language support, review the numbers 1 to 5 in their home language. The group can practice counting aloud in English, holding up the number of fingers for each number said.
This is a fast-moving activity and children may be distracted by noise or other outside stimuli. Keeping calm and talking the child through the activity can help with sensory issues.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: As we read Five Creatures, we talked about using our working memory to help us understand the story.
You can use your working memory to play memory games with cards.

First, you will see all of the pictures on the cards. Each card will show a number of things. Take a good look because I am going to turn the cards over! When it is your turn, try to make a match by finding two cards showing the same number of things.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Randomly place the Activity Cards in two rows of cards on the table, with the picture side showing. Ask children how many items they see on each card before turning that card over. Do this for all cards.

Ask Can you find two cards that have the same number of things? The first child turns over two cards. Ask, how many on each card? If both cards show the same number of items, that is a match and the child keeps the cards. If the cards do not match, the child turns both cards back over and it is the next child’s turn.
Repeat Continue until all of the matches are found. As time permits, shuffle the cards and play again.
Extend Have children find sets of one to five items in the classroom.

Talk About Working Memory Talk to children about how they use their working memories every day. They listened to the rules for the activity and then worked to remember them. Help children come up with more examples from the school day.

Have children play the game with the cards facing up. Have them identify two cards that they think have matching numbers. Provide support as they count the number of items on each card and decide whether they have the same amount.
Ask children to announce which number they are looking for before turning two cards over. If they find a pair, but it is not the number they named, they do not keep the match.
As you discuss working memory after the activity, encourage multilingual learners to share how they pair words in two languages in their memories and translate what they hear to help them remember.
Children can use tweezers to turn over the Activity Cards to practice their fine motor skills. You can also have children help you set the cards with their tweezers at the beginning of each round.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need different-sized blocks.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: As we read Five Creatures, we talked about short and long or tall when we talked about the family’s hair, their height, and the stools they sit on.
Let’s review the words short and long.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Use the short and long Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, you will find five blocks that are a mix of short and long. You will use them to build towers that are short and tall.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Ask each child to find five blocks of at least two different lengths. Help the children make sure some of the blocks are longer than others and that they have five blocks in all.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Sort your blocks from longest to shortest. Build a tower using the blocks you found. Put the longest block on the bottom and the shortest block on the top.
Build two towers with your blocks. Make one tall tower and one short tower.
How can you tell which block is longer and which block is shorter? How did you compare the blocks?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Talk About Counting Have children share how they chose their blocks. Ask children to count the blocks they used, starting with the shortest block. Repeat, but have children count their blocks starting with the longest. Guide children to understand that the number of blocks remains the same no matter which order they are counted in.
Help children position two blocks side by side with the end of each block in the same position. Explain that the block that is taller can also be described as longer. The other block is shorter.
Give children up to five toys or objects from the classroom and have them order the objects by height. Ask children to order the objects from shortest to longest and then longest to shortest.

For children who may need more language support, give visual examples of taller and shorter. Refer to the images on the Vocabulary Cards as an example before the children answer on their own. Say the words aloud as you point to each picture, and have children repeat after you.
Have children use their whole bodies to discuss measuring height. Have them hold their hands close to the ground as they say shorter. Then have children raise their hands high and say taller.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, provide children with paper and crayons.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Let’s review the words creatures, grandparents, and grandchild. Use the creatures, grandparents, and grandchild Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.
As we read My Family and Me, we talked about different creatures in a family. We saw families with mothers, fathers, brothers, sisters, aunts, uncles, cousins, grandparents, a grandchild, and pets.
In this activity, you will say how many creatures you see in each family and then count them one-by-one to check.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Play Show children the Activity Cards one at a time. Challenge children to tell how many creatures without counting. Then have children check by counting each family member, including animals. Remind children that the counting order does not matter.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: How many creatures are in this family? How do you know?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Repeat Continue the activity until each child has had a chance to count at least two families.
Extend Have children make an Activity Card that shows their family.
Talk About Family Discuss with children the creatures they drew in their family. Help children count them. Remind children to include any pets, and be flexible as to who is a family member.
Have children place a Two-Color Counter on each person as they count to make sure they count each person only once.
Ask children questions about different sets of people. How many grandparents are in this picture? How many children? How many parents? How many people in all?
For children who may need language support, have them bring a picture of their own family to connect the content to what they already know. Help them tell who is in their picture.
Have children build fine motor skills by drawing a picture to match one of the Activity Cards. Ask children to share their drawings with the group.
